commentBody: Smashed my PR for Sunday by several minutes. The puzzle was definitely on my wavelength after a tough Saturday. Ole!

Th 20:03
Fr 20:03
Sa 21:16
Su 20:54

That's quite a narrow range for the second half this week
Went fairly quickly today. Don‚Äôt usually get to post this soon.  Loved the puzzle!

How do you not clue WEDDINGDURESS as ‚ÄúShotgun marriage‚Äù?!

I thought this was a fine puzzle and actually fairly chewy for me. Some of the clues were a little DRAB like SOMETHINGBOLD and BEASTMAN while PARITYPLANNER and MOTHERINLAWN made me laugh.

I thought WINEFRAUD was a stretch but I guess it‚Äôs a thing.
Clever as hell. Really loved it! Nice work.
Fastest Sunday this year (by two seconds, over Jan. 12)

First the trailers dated. Then they got hitched.

(They're in it for the long haul.)

An aspirin after celebrating too much?
Checking that the patent leather shoes are fastened?
Drama over who bought the most expensive gift?




HEAD TABLET
TRYING THE KNOT
PRICE THROWING

But Ruth and Hannah‚Äôs choices were really funny!
I'm still chuckling at MOTHER IN LAWN.
Great puzzle! Loved the theme. Thanks!

This puzzle really has an attitude about weddings, no?

GRIFTREGISTRY, BEASTMAN, WEDDINGDURESS...

I loved it.  Really an amazingly delightful solve.

My only problem was I was pretty severely naticked at 50D and 61A.  Airport letters are hard to make a reasonable guess about, and I know palm trees like a polar bear.
Mother in lawn! ü§£

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Hannah Margolin, and on your relatively recent marriage! I hope you and your spouse have many happy years together! My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review of this charming puzzle: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/06/21/sunday-june-22-2025/
I was certainly 100D this entire puzzle. A fun one, nevertheless.
More puzzles like this please! Till deaRth us do part!
I enjoyed this puzzle, but it took me a long time to figure out the themed clues enough for them to help me with the rest of the puzzle.
Haha.
Can someone explain how wallop = paste?? I was stuck on that one.

Talk about putting the "H" in HOMES: Here's "She Lit a Fire," by Ben Schneider, aka Lord Huron. Much of the video was filmed at the Schneider family "place" on--you guessed it--Lake Huron. "Good thing the neighbors were away." But some stunning shots at the end of Tahquamenon Falls (I can now spell that without looking it up!); Wouldn't that be a lovely place for some wedding photos? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VUxh-jw-C-w&list=RDVUxh-jw-C-w&start_radio=1
Take me forever (about 20 minutes to figure out it wasn't SOMETHINGGOLD/DRAG.
loved how cutthroat the reveals were must be some power wedding! congrats either way hope the love flows and doesn't end up like some of those very funny answers
Clever clues, lively fill, and terrible puns. Just how I like my Sunday puzzles.
Once I got one of the theme clues, the rest weren't hard. Can someone explain why 4-D is highlighted?

Very funny puzzle. Especially liked MOTHER IN LAWN.

Wedded at a medieval tournament?
JOUST MARRIED

The groom at the medieval tournament?
WEDDING KNIGHT

Maids of honor?
WEDDING BELLES

Marking sections of The Inferno for your best man speech?
SAVE THE DANTE

Teetotaler's choice at the open bar?
MATCHA MADE IN HEAVEN

Ask Leo X to preside?
POPE THE QUESTION
A classic Sunday puzzle. Big thank you to the constructors.

Duane, Nat, Awkwafina, Ocasek, FWIW (great song, by the way). Such a great start to a great puzzle. What? No Swifty clues?

My favorite clues:
¬ª Lay low‚Ä¶ I LOVE it!
¬ª Driver‚Äôs warning caused me a chuckle and an AHA moment. Hint, when you slice it in the woods, no need for a fore!

Under the heading of Only In NJ:
¬ª Wallop = paste? ‚ÄúI'll paste ya right in the mouth, ya little twerp.‚Äù

Mother-in-lawn, genius! En masse, they can aerate my lawn.üòé

Head scratchers:
¬ª Twee? Brit speak?
¬ª Oner?
¬ª Exurb, a portmanteau?
¬ª Much = far?
¬ª NEA and not NRA, wow!

Note to future self; MNOP no longer precedes Q. I'll just sashay my ducks into a row. I hesitated at 72D, but thank goodness one can still FAIL. 6 on a phone is still MNO and not... ya know, whew!

I was all over those famous Doctors, but, much to my chagrin, Drs. Phil, Detroit and Beeper didn't make the cut. Curses!

I'm very familiar with the Hasidic Jews, but I guess I‚Äôll take ‚ÄòHasidim‚Äô. Good people, very philanthropic and great to talk with.

A puzzle well constructed!
Enjoyed this. How were we to know - based on the clue formatting - that XRAYLAB wasn‚Äôt part of the themed clues? Took me forever bc I was searching for something wedding-y.

Misled.  

Kinda like how I thought my wedding would be less than a certain dollar amount.
Was this the first NYTC appearance of "twee"?

Fantastic construction built around a great theme! So many LOL moments threaded throughout the grid. My husband was sitting next to me as I solved this and he was chuckling as well üòÜ Congratulations on your debut, Hannah, and how exciting to share that experience with your mother! I really enjoyed your work and hope to see more

Wish I might hire a cashbard to better articulate happiness, awe, and a touch of envy for this mother- daughter debut.

Thank you, Hannah and Ruth, for sharing a snapshot of your union, at the altar and grid, it seems.

For 15 years, my dearest Mother posted NYT puzzle bundles to little lonely me overseas- clipped at the table she shared with the love of her life. Those crosswords, and her notes, kept me grounded.

I wish you both continued peace and joy, and look forward to your next collaboration.

"Love is a gift of one's innermost soul to another, so both can be whole."
‚ò∏Ô∏è
A fun and clever puzzle --- thank you!

My invalid aunt still retained a sharp mind and every day I‚Äôd phone so we could do the NYT puzzle together. I‚Äôm completing 
this one alone wiping the happy tears from my glasses as I think of her. Thank you for this gift.

I have a streak that dates back to November of 2020. In over 1,650 puzzles during this time, this was one of the most delightful I have had the privilege of solving. It helps that I got married less than a year ago, so all of the phrases that had "plus ones" in them were front of mind! Thank you, Ruth and Hannah, for putting a huge smile on my face with it!

A nit about 99A [Rugby scuffle]. In Rugby (Union, the form most seen in the USA) a. SCRUM is a highly structured and controlled action. It is in the rucks and mauls, related but quite different actions, that we see what appears to be scuffling.
FWIW?? It‚Äôs??? Someone explain please üò≠

@Caitlin Lovinger Besides the fact that it has too many letters, the answer to 101A could not have been weedingPLANNER because you'd have to remove one of the Ds from wedding, and the theme requires us to add one letter to the phrase, not subtract anything. But you probably figured that out.

I got DOOKed by MISLED. I heard it in my head as "missiled" and it wasn't until I was reading the comments and saw the word written in context that I got it.  I wouldn't say I've ever felt misled by clues. Misdirected, yes. 

I had AwOkE before AROSE, which worked at first because I also had AVow before AVER, and kept trying to think of another Ric since the K in OCASEK seemed to be in the wrong place. 

I'm just tired. Spent the day SASHAYing around a theme park with friends and nursing a very strong cocktail, but not from a COCONUT. I hardly ever drink these days, so between that and the sun and screaming MADLY on roller coasters, I'm ready for bed.

You know I'm tired because I just looked at the puzzle again and wondered what REAIMS (pronounced "ree-ims") means.
Also, can someone please explain CASH BARD to me? I know what a BARD is. I'm wondering what CASH has to do with it. Is it just because you're hiring them? Or am I missing something?
Cash bar at a wedding?

I think we can all agree MOTHERINLAWN is a real humdinger! Made me laugh out loud. Kudos. 

(I wonder if there was a temptation to go with SMOTHERINLAW, which is surely what many of us want to do in the years to wedded bliss)

Delightful romp. A lot of good wordplay, I loved WINEFRAUD.
It was fun to see which wedding-related phrases would emerge--albeit somewhat altered. More puzzles like this one, please.
Can someone explain [Real lulu] = ONER?
WHO sadly didn‚Äôt work
One of the most delightful puzzles I‚Äôve ever had the pleasure to solve. Figured out the stilettoed parent and the rest unfolded into a lovely little wedding album.
Thanks Hannah and Ruth for a laugh-out-loud solve. 68A a winner.

Hi everyone. 

I enjoyed the wedding puns today, but I can't for the life of me see the gag with SOMETHING BOLD.  What does "something old" have to do with weddings or is it something else? Can someone please help? Thanks.

This one put up a lot of resistance for me, and took a few passes through the grid to finally get the theme. I figured out that the theme entries were altered (altared? üòâ ) phrases but didn‚Äôt get that they were all wedding related and required adding only one letter until pretty late in my solve, when I finally realized SHAVETHEfAcE wasn‚Äôt a variation of ‚Äúsave face‚Äù and was actually SHAVETHEDATE. 

Someone commented below that they weren‚Äôt sure why an E for Everyone rating is necessary for a video game. As someone with little kids, I find it useful in the same way the G ratings on movies are useful in establishing what media needs less scrutiny or discussion before allowing my kids to watch or play. 

Happy anniversary to all those whose weddings took place in June! Just celebrated sweet sixteen with my spouse this past week. ü•∞

As someone who dreads the day a wedding invitation appears in the mail (quick!  Start thinking of excuses!), the phrases did not come that readily to me and almost made me break out in hives.  

Once I got past that, it was a fun solve.

Does this puzzle take you to a happier place than the thought of sitting through an actual wedding?

IT DO.

(Sorry to all the wedding fans out there.)

There‚Äôs ha-ha happiness and there‚Äôs warm-the-heart happiness, and for me, today‚Äôs puzzle pulsed with both.

First of all, it‚Äôs wedding-centered, based on an event where the heart often swells with elation, where the eyes often fill with the best tears, where the air is filled with delight, merriment, and high spirits.  Where love is palpable.

Then, it‚Äôs made by a mom and daughter.  As I imagine them working side-by-side, laughing and high-fiving at coming up with finds that land, cocooning in earnest while brainstorming and chiseling their creation, well, that‚Äôs a mom-daughter relationship that touches my heart, that reminds me that so much good pervades this world.

Also, this is a puzzle whose purpose is more than just to create riddles to crack ‚Äì it‚Äôs also to entertain.  It wants to get us to smile and even burst out with a ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù or giggle.  Who doesn‚Äôt like that?

It succeeded with me, kept me in a jolly good mood throughout, punctuated by genuine laughs, while keeping my brain happy untangling clues and theme answers. 

Crossword success in the highest.  Started with an empty box, and exiting feeling, through and through, that life is good.  Wow and thank you, Ruth and Hannah!
Does anyone know why REVEAL (4 down) is highlighted in green?

A mother-daughter team constructing a wedding-themed crossword puzzle - this surely takes the cake! As the news 
on the front page gets grimmer, it sure is nice have to have heart-warming stories such as this emerge from the ‚Äúback pages.‚Äù 
Ladies, keep the puzzles coming!

tc

Really clever. The first of the plus ones had me hating the answer since surely there‚Äôs no such thing as a grift registry. As I got the theme I grew to love the plus ones. 

One side note. When on the iPad app the title of the puzzle isn‚Äôt shown until the end. Might have been handy to have this clue at the start.

The theme was great fun. Really amazing.

Clever cues - LAW, LAY LOW, GNUS

I stalled on a few names as usual - NORA Lum changed her name to Awkwafina?Didn't know her and couldn't guess that one!

H for HURON? Could someone help?

Re discussion about trivia:
For me
Brand name 112 A
90 Minute TV show 120 A 
Who knows how long tv programmes are?

I just love the family collaborations.

It adds something so pure
and nostalgic and cozy and delightful
to the solve.

Thank you both for this one.

Smile on my face is big.

üëç üëç
I was at a wedding the night before this puzzle's publication, so its timing was perfect for my solving. It was a fun theme.

Well I was going to suggest that this is another fine POY candidate until I read Barry‚Äôs comment regarding charming and easy. Oof! My mileage varied. It was definitely charming, but like Eric H, I had to chew a little harder. I finished a few minutes over my average time, and for me the clever wordplay punctuated the solving experience with good humor.
.
Either way, thanks to Ruth and Hannah for this clever crowd pleaser. And your mother/daughter notes. For your next puzzle you might want to bring in @john ezra.
I have to ask my Gen-Z kids if GRIFTREGISTRY is a thing.  If not, it needs to be!

I was hopeful that all the "plus ones" would add up to spell a wedding-related word or phrase.  As a result I find myself a bit disappointed at the end of this solve.

Which is a shame, because it's a pretty nice puzzle.  I love the idea of a mother/daughter construction team, and it's cool that the original seed phrase arose as Hannah's wedding was being planned.
And MOTHER IN LAWN is sheer genius.

Never felt on the constructors' wavelengths, but in the end I really liked this puzzle. The theme was clever, and I even smiled in response to my mental image of a MOTHERINLAWN.

Given the amount of thematic content in the grid, the fill seemed pretty solid, all in all. I'm willing to overlook AWORD, AROW, EAN and OWOE.

Liked the creative uses of the two X's: XRAYLAB/EXURB and LEOX/TAXFORM.

Seeing "Queue before Q", for some reason today I immediately entered MNOP. Wrong there, but then MNO appeared in response to "6, on a phone"!

Fun puzzle. Solved it unaided, but took me 45 minutes. That doesn't include the additional 20 minutes I spent seeking meaning in HDUREBIAN.

I thought I was struggling but my time was 10 minutes less than my average. 
It was a fun puzzle with some great clues.
Mickey Rooney said it‚Äôs best to get married in the morning, because if it doesn‚Äôt work out, you haven‚Äôt wasted the whole day.

Some nice cluing and resourceful construction, but for me it was a plod. I wasn't on the constructors' wavelength at all, either with regard to the cluing, or the punning. So I progressed in fits and starts, punctuated by long pauses.

Perhaps others will have commented on the idea that a rugby SCRUM is a "scuffle".
ONER is new to me, XRAY LAB, WINE FRAUD and RATED E unfamiliar. CASH BARD was the first themer to fall, but it was no help, given that I don't know the expression CASH BAR, and only figured that one out after completion.

I had one lookup, to crack my final two cells at the northern edge. [Rocker Ric] was unknown, and I couldn't see A WORD without his name, or RATED E without A WORD. So it goes. Perhaps a little more thought would have revealed them for me, but I was quite keen for it to be over.

I had been done with the puzzle for almost an hour before I realized that the "Leo" who works for MGM Studios is not "DiCaprio", but the lion who roars at the start of every MGM movie.
Anyone else?  Or am I just slow this morning?

I completed  this  clever, well polished puzzle with enthusiasm (despite many lookups) the morning after  a surprise engagement party for my grandson and his beautiful inside-and--out bride to be.   I was delighted to celebrate the union between a  U.S.-born nice Jewish boy with Ukrainian ancestors  who arrived here in the late 1800s and English ancestors who arrived here in 1620, and a nice Indian -American girl born in the U.S. of physician parents who immigrated from Goa in the 20th century, and became pillars of their community.  My grandson works for an organization that helps immigrants.  His fianc√©e is an RN.  (They did not meet through the immigrant organization )  As the oldest person in the room by at least 25 years, I was thrilled by the smart, charming, generous young people there, all of them highly educated professionals involved in socially useful  work.  Why am I sharing all this with you? Because I rejoice that this union will enrich community.   I hope your wedding invitations make you  think of what's happening to our country as a result of them. Plus1  expresses  this thought very well, I think.

Wowser-dowser! (As DHubby is prone to say.)  Would you believe it?!  My final entry was TADA!
This was really fun, and the sly clues were especially clever.  

What's the most unique WEDDING you have ever been to?  Our son and his fiance√© and friends planned their Masquerade Wedding--on Halloween--and guests were encouraged to come in costume.  (We were DON the DON with his MOLL.)  Great fun!

Oh, the puzzle.  A-Plus!  More, please!
I didn‚Äôt think this was one of the trickier Sunday puzzles. I was looking for more than just removing one letter when I looked at the clue.
fun theme! definitely some odd answers in this puzzle. I didn't seem to connect with the creator with a lot of the clues. happy Sunday!

How ironic. I completed this puzzle the day after my husband and I hosted a party to celebrate the wedding of our grandson. Since the wedding was at Gulf Shores, many of our huge family couldn't attend; It was a blast, just like this puzzle.

Started out with the Bee this AM, and it wouldn't accept "teenie," which fit all the letters allowed.  OK, so moved on to Sunday Crossword, and came to ___________-weenie. I thought, "Well isn't this interesting - what else that fits the clue could they be thinking of?" Failing to come up with anything, I decided to see if the NYT had double standards (I realize it's two different authors), and sure enough, the puzzle accepted Teenie!  Oh, the irony!
WINE FRAUD crossing with GRIFT REGISTRY was *chef‚Äôs kiss*
When I went to the cash bard, he gave me a twist of rhyme with my cocktail.

Fun puzzle today, thank you, Ruth and Hannah.

Just hung up for a little while over blinis vs. LATKEs.
Settled for blueberry pancakes for this morning's breakfast.

The more I think about GRIFT REGISTRY, the less it makes sense. Returning gifts isn't grifty behavior, and obviously you're going to keep the money cause it was a gift? Surely nobody who returns a gift then gives the money back to the gifter?!

I know I'm over-thinking it, but it's a clever pun with a half-baked clue.

I recently watched a murder mystery where the plot revolved around WINE FRAUD. In the opening scene, a body is found face-down in a vat if Shiraz. Anyway, I tried to make that fit with the "plus one" theme, but to no avail, unless a wine frau is some kind of female sommelier.

Loved this puzzle, so much fun! Not a clunker to be found. SHAVE THE DATE was my favorite themer.
Pardon, but could someone explain SOMETHING BOLD? Specifically, which letter ought to be removed and why ü§î

re NJ (for @Jerry especially but also @Beth in Greebelt, @Eric Houghland and @Barry Ancona)..always gets no respect. Eons ago, when dinosaurs roamed the earth and smoking was allowed on airplanes, I was an impecunious grad student in Chicago occasionally flying to family in NY's Westchester county. There was a (now defunct) Pittsburgh-based airline that had cheap flights from LaGuardia. But they always involved changing planes in Pittsburgh and LGA's on-time record was so bad that one frequently missed the connection.  So Newark was the much better option and I do not recall anything bad about it. Plus a far easier drive than out to Long Island. 
Viva New Jersey!
Where can I find the title of the puzzle?  I solve in the app, and I can‚Äôt see it.
What a good day for a straightforward, entertaining Sunday puzzle.

Not the trickiest Sunday grid but still a delightful one. Love the wedding-y theme. Joining others in the wedding coincidence file, I spent this morning with daughter and sister in law, who‚Äôs the florist, at the wedding venue planning the floral arrangements. Good fun.

Got the gist with SHAVE THE DATE, had fun working out the rest. 117A made me chuckle.

We‚Äôre getting a couple of SHOATS next year, heading for the freezer come Autumn. They will be dubbed Apple and Sauce. Yum.
Cute puzzle, but why does the clue for WINEFRAUD have a question mark?  It's not part of the theme trick...

I loved this puzzle! I had a mistake with the Motorspots Hall-of-Famer, I had UNSER in there, which of course doesn't work.  And there is a great  television mystery about wine fraud, called "Hidden Depths." It is an episode of Midsomer Murders, and is really fun.
Nice puzzle, but I'm mostly just impressed with myself for completing it in under an hour, considering my brain has melted. Hope everyone is staying cool!

Loved this puzzle from the get-go, and when I found out the constructors were mother and daughter, it got even better. And from Westfield, no less, one of the loveliest places of my youth, where we'd often visit old friends of my parents. I was happily off-balance for most of today's solve, and the image of a mother (or mother-in-law) in high heels, embedded in a freshly mowed lawn was an absolute delight. I attended a family wedding last month in the Berkshires on a rainy Saturday evening at the bride's father's home, with 150 of us moving under the tent to attend the ceremony and avoid the downpour. By the end of the evening, we were all happily drenched.

Came so close to having to do a look-up or two today. Did get the "At least one word's amiss" message and spent an extra 15 minutes flyspecking.

I thought WIrEFRAUD made a lot of sense as a vintage racket, although I could make no sense of pro BOrO. When correcting that did not lead to the happy music I was dismayed because that was the only spot I was unsure of. 

I couldn't remember whether the crocodile hunter was ERWIN or IRWIN, but was so sure that HASIDeM had to be right that it took way too long to decide to try another vowel there. Finally finished this close to my old Sunday times of 8 years ago.

My favorite is MOTHERINLAWN. I've attempted to walk across grass in heels before and know the sinking feeling. But imagining a dignified matron in lace and pearls mired deep in the turf is truly a delicious mental image.
This was a fun puzzle to solve on my 29th wedding anniversary! Like marriage, some parts were more enjoyable than others. Some groaners and some real head scratchers, but worth sticking it out.

Strands #476
‚ÄúFragrant abuse‚Äù
üîµüü°üîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

No spoilers above the fold üòâ
Oh man, I loved every single thing about this puzzle ‚Äì great job and thank you Ruth and Hannah!
Very puzzle and deeply appreciated all the Shakespeare references!

Cute theme, enjoyed it. Kept getting the oops message and spent way too long looking for my typo and finding nothing amiss. Turns out I had an error at 86A/71D that seemed perfectly reasonable: SOMETHINGGOLD for the sequin jacket, and therefore, DRAG for lackluster (as in a party). Anyone else?

Several people have noted that when you highlight the answer at 4-Down, it appears to be green, rather than the traditional blue.
Why???
@Jerry had an excellent suggestion that it has to do with the "Gender REVEAL" event.
At these events, "blue" means the baby is a boy; "pink" means that the baby is a girl; and "green" means that the parents have decided not to know the gender of the baby in advance.

By making the answer green (rather than blue), the constructors are keeping us in suspense (and avoiding gender bias)!
I hope this explanation is true and that it's not just a glitch in the program.

(Cont'd)
OPHELIA:
(She wrings her hands.)
Neither fits! Neither! This puzzle is a torment! It speaks of worlds unknown to me! What am I to do, Hamlet? My mind reels! Mine own wits art scatt'r'd like autumn leaves!
HAMLET:
(Patting her shoulder awkwardly.)
Calm yourself, Ophelia. It is but a game. A trifle.
OPHELIA:
A trifle?! It is a testament to my ignorance! A cruel mirror reflecting my own inadequacies! I cannot solve it, Hamlet! I cannot!
(Her eyes grow wide, a strange light entering them.)
OPHELIA (cont.):
I see... I see the patterns now! The hidden messages! The grid is not random! It is a map! A map to‚Ä¶ to a place where knowledge is not confined by tiny boxes!
(She starts to back away, her voice growing distant.)
OPHELIA (cont.):
I must‚Ä¶ I must go! To a place where puzzles hold no sway! Where ignorance is bliss!
HAMLET:
(Reaching for her.)
Ophelia, wait! Where do you go?
OPHELIA:
(Her eyes fix on some unseen point in the distance.)
To a nunnery! Yes! Where the only riddles are matters of faith! Where the vocabulary is limited to prayer and piety! Fare thee well, Hamlet! Fare thee well, cruel puzzle!
(Ophelia rushes from the chamber, leaving a bewildered Hamlet staring at the New Yorick Times Sunday Puzzle. He slowly lowers it, a look of confusion on his face.)
HAMLET:
... A nunnery? For a wordsquare puzzle? Truly, Something is rotten in the state of Denmark. That one may smile and smile and be a villain.... and perhaps, about the content of these Times.
[SCENE ENDS]
Does anyone else see the answer to 4-down in a different color? Mine is pea green when highlighted, rather than the typical blue. Color me confused

On TWEE ...
A good century old in British English. Today I learned it originated in imitation of a child's pronunciation of "sweet", and was originally a good thing, more or less synonymous with how (some) folk use "cute" about kittens.
But my understanding dates from around the 1960s, I think, when my grandmother's "front room", full of doilies and china dogs, might be called twee---fussy and unfashionable.

I've only learned the current usage, typified by [Overly precious] today, since I started doing NYT crosswords.

[INDOOR - A sun-drenched chamber in Elsinore Castle. OPHELIA is hunched over a large sheet of paper, furrowing her brow. It is the NEW YORICK TIMES SUNDAY WORDSQUARE.]
OPHELIA:
O, woe is me. T'have seen what I have seen, see what I see!
(She gestures wildly at the wordsquare puzzle, her hands trembling.)
OPHELIA (cont.):
This‚Ä¶ this‚Ä¶ labyrinth of letters! This tyranny of tiny boxes! I have wrestled with kings and princes, yet this... this "theme" defies my very soul! "Nine Letters, "Vintage racket?"? What vintner's goods could possibly fit the pattern? Is it Mead? Nay, too short! Wine? Five letters astray! I am lost!
(Hamlet enters, carrying a quill pen.)
HAMLET:
Ophelia, fair Ophelia. What troubles you this morn? Is it the weight of the court?
OPHELIA:
(She throws the puzzle down in exasperation.)
Nay, Hamlet! 'Tis this infernal wordsquare! It mocks me! It whispers secrets of forgotten facts and esoteric knowledge! "A five-letter word for an obscure catcher of unagi," it says! "A six-letter word for a breed of young pig!" My knowledge of pigs is shamefully lacking, my lord!
HAMLET:
(Picking up the puzzle, trying to appear helpful.)
Ah, the Sunday puzzle. A challenge, indeed. Let me see. "Catcher of unagi"‚Ä¶ Hmm. An eel of the East, "A man may fish with the worm that hath eat of a king, and eat of the eel that hath fed of that worm".
HAMLET: FORSOOTH! A Character in "The Crown"! Heavy is the head that wears the crown, dear Ophelia. Hmm, Lady Anne appears here.
(Cont'd)
Clever puns. I especially like 'grift registry' - I've been invited to a few of those parties!
I also liked I SURELY DO as theme-related even if it‚Äôs a plus-six :)

A very fine Sunday puzzle, with a fun theme and best of all, clues that took some thinking about before they could be filled in. I very much appreciate when Sunday a puzzle cannot be solved too quickly.
Great fun here. Lots of clever wordplay but I laughed the loudest at the silliest answer -- the beast man. As for non themers the clue for inter was really deep.
A solid Sunday solve.  Thankful for the thoroughly thoughtful theme.  Able to avail an average addition to the annals.
A solid Sunday solve.  Thankful for the thoroughly thoughtful theme.  Able to avail an average addition to the annals.

Great puzzle. I had LAPS for 'What's broken for a record' and managed to convince myself that PINE FRAUD is a thing and probably related to poor quality tennis rackets made of pine wood. Took me ages before I realized my idiocy.
I really enjoyed this! So funny. It was hard but for me but not miserable. 10/10.
Had BREACH/BOPIN in lieu of PREACH/POPIN. Couldn‚Äôt find my error for the longest time!
Delightful! Keep collaborating!

This was not only one of the most entertaining Sunday puzzles I‚Äôve encountered, it produced one of the most lively comments sections, as well. So many great puns! 

I‚Äôll be picturing Mother in Lawn for a long time‚Ä¶ ü§£

This was a nice one - a straightforward difficulty level making for a fun stove, with a cute theme. What a wonderful puzzle! An entertaining theme, clever clues, and some fiendishly delightful lateral thinking. My favorite puzzle of 2025. Well done!

as i've noted before, my son and i do do the puzzle together almost every day. we first started when we were home together during covid and he was in high school. our current streak is 499 as of today, so it was especially nice to read about ruth and hannah as a mother/daughter team who started out solving together. my son has tried his hand at puzzle construction, and i imagine we will collaborate one day. well, i hope so, anyway!

favorite answers today: GRIFTREGISTRY, CASHBARD, and MOTHERINLAWN; i laughed out loud at the last two!

thanks, ruth and hannah, for a great sunday solve. i hope you are keeping cool on this steamy ny/nj day. and i hope you collaborate on more puzzles! 

p.s. i was pleasantly surprised that the answer to 106A was HASIDIM, as i didn't realize that term was used outside the hebrew/yiddish speaking community!

Pet peeve of mine, but MILK CAN ONLY COME FROM TEATS! Mammary glands produce milk and a defining characteristic of mammals is milk production from mammary glands. Ergo, plant matter cannot produce milk. It is deliberately false advertising to call something oat milk or soy milk, when really, it is juice. However, juice has negative connotations as being unhealthy. Still, the best kind of correct is technically correct, and so STOP CALLING PLANT MATTER MILK!

When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the Navy reserved all codes starting with N. NEWaRk, then, used the other letters in its name to make EWR.

@Jerry

TWEE is "chiefly British", but it's showing up in the US a bit these days.  It's supposedly "sweet" in baby talk.

ONER is read "one-er".  It's probably short for "one of a kind".  It has been used 603 times (though, surprisingly, not in the past five years), so remember it.  It will appear again, no doubt!

EXURB isn't a portmanteau any more than "suburb" is.  The EXURBs are the parts of the "metropolitan area" of a city that isn't metropolitan at all.  There are likely to be as many cows as people, but the suburban train reaches the main town there (at the end of the line, as the puzzle says).

I will remind you that the way crossword cluing conventions work, if either version of rugby satisfies the clue, the answer is valid.

There's nothing to indicate that the NYT crossword staff doesn't know there are two versions of rugby.

A ONER I think of as a 'one-off' but more usually I've heard it as "I did it in a oner" meaning I only needed one shot at it.

@Tiva

I'd never heard of ONER. My old OED defines it as "a person or thing of a unique or remarkable kind", which is a match for the non-ironic use of"lulu". 
But all its citations are from the nineteenth century. I quite like:

Thackeray (1862): "You should see her eat; she is such a oner at eating."

The on-line OED has added a couple of twentieth-century citations---one from a collection of Australian slang (1959), and one from a dictionary of American slang (1987).

Which all probably explains why I'd never heard of it!

@Darren, there was no random or incorrect spelling in this puzzle. The theme was clever, and once deduced, followed a pattern that was simple to execute. I'm attending three weddings this summer so all the phrases were in the forefront of my mind. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

On Sunday you get an "in" for the mind of the constructor from the title. Part of solving a puzzle is thinking about what the theme could be, and what tricks might be afoot. If you don't enjoy exercising your brain, why do you do crossword puzzles?
